Dear Adriene,


I'm not sure you're going to read this, you must have a lot to do and countless comments coming in every day. But on the off chance that you will, I wanted to thank you. (This is going to be a bit long).


Last year was kind of rough. In fact, my entire life has been kind of rough, but last year was particularly bad. I drank and smoked heavily, did not exercise and kind of neglected my diet most days. I was not in a good place emotionally and it showed physically. I turned over a new leaf in January; quit drinking and smoking, started taking care of myself again and remembered my trusted old friend Yoga With Adriene (I have been with you in the past before everything went a bit nuts). I have been doing your exercises almost daily since then and I'm not going to lie: it was hard. I had lost a lot of my flexibility, my breathing was messed up, but most importantly: I couldn't just be anymore. I am a naturally anxious and perfectionistic person to an unhealthy degree. I am very hard on myself and because of this, much of yoga in the past and back in January was just 'getting that pose down perfectly, you know, like in the picture!'. I'd practise in front of the mirror, force my body into the poses just so they looked good but neglected the feeling. When you tell us 'find what feels good' I told myself this was what I was doing, but it wasn't. I was too preoccupied with getting everything just right and in so doing, actually forgot a lot of important things along the way. I couldn't keep my core engaged because I was so focussed on touching my chest to my leg in forward fold, my breathing was ragged and uncontrolled, I couldn't lift from my body but dumped weight into my wrists because the soles of my feet just had to touch the ground in down dog. As always, I was thinking too much, being too critical of myself and forgot why I wanted to do yoga again in the first place. It's an easy thing for me to fall into.


The past week has been very rough for me emotionally and I haven't been back on the mat until today. This flow was beautiful. It was energising and touched on the exact basic yoga poses and flowing through them the way I needed today and I noticed that I could finally be present. Listen to my body, find what feels good and be aware of everything going on in my body. I stopped focussing on getting everything 'like in the picture' and as a result, actually focussed on the movement and flow. I rose high lunge without shaking, strong and balanced like I'm supposed to because for the first time, I focussed on the present, on everything in my body and finally, my mind could tune out all the outside stuff that makes me so crazy all the time.


You did this for me, Adriene. You give me these little moments of peace and quiet amidst chaos (both on the outside and inside) and I thank you dearly for it. Namaste.

This one was hard for me. I haven't practiced in over 2 months. I do often fall in and out of doing yoga quite dramatically, I have a lot of negative emotions around that as what I really want (but don't do) is to have a daily practice and be progressing - that may be physically or mentally. I'll admit it does bother me that I am all or nothing with this, and have been for 10 years. About 2 years ago I was dead set on doing my yoga teacher training, but in my mind I wasn't quite "there" yet with my physical and mental practice. Since then I have again gone through the on-again-off-again roller coaster. Last year I spent the first five months of the year practicing nearly daily. I was proud of myself, I am still. That was started off with the 30-days of Yoga journey, something that tends to revitalise me. This year I did maybe half of the 30 days of yoga month and dropped off after that. I was annoyed at myself, I still am.

Today I found this practice really hard. I tried my best to notice any negative thoughts that were coming through and dismiss them although I know some of these thoughts are "true" for lack of a better word. I found myself out of breath immediately, I was shaking, I felt generally really weak (I could barley lift my arms, couldn't hold a downward dog), I had to take breaks. I know that all of this is part of the practice and I have no reason to feel bad about this - I'm sure if anyone does read this they can relate to being your own worst critic. If I was reading this comment from someone else's perspective I would be sending loving vibes and words of encouragement. Ultimately I know in my heart this is fine, more than fine. I am proud of myself for getting up and onto the mat in the first place - I have been at home for 3 days in isolation so I have done nothing more than sit on the couch and browse social media. I feel today will be different.

It is frustrating to lose (although I know it is not lost) the strength I built last year and to not be able to motivate myself. I find myself torn between the voice in my head that is saying I am "weak" and "if only I had kept up with my practice I could have been somewhere different by now" and the other voice that is loving and caring and accepts me no matter what the circumstance. What I said at the beginning of this comment is true... I do want to have a daily practice. I want to motivate myself regardless of situation. I want to progress - what ever that means. I want to look back on myself in a year and know I made good choices that have benefitted me. This is is longest comment I have EVER left on youtube and I have been on here about about 12 years.

To anyone reading - I am looking for change. A change to my practice that is permanent. I have learned so much from yoga and it has helped me in so many ways, I struggle to understand why I continue this flip-flop attitude towards it. I want it to be different.

Hello, everyone. ğŸ˜Š I wanted to share my story cuz maybe it will mean something to other people. I have been doing sports my entire life, was always in a great shape and never had any injuries. 2 years ago I started practicing yoga (ashtanga vinyasa) and I got addicted. This addiction turned out to be bad for me just like any other addiction is bad. But I couldn't realize how bad it was because in my mind I was doing something good like cmon it's yoga, I imagined that this type of movement is different from all others as if guided by some invisible divine hand and nothing bad can ever come of it. I was in a really good shape and at first I couldn't feel any pain. I was practising 6 days a week for 2 hours or more. My teachers have been telling me "Breathe through the pain" "It is normal to feel that, you are changing your body" "That tension means that you are releasing something buried deep within" and so on. I never questioned it. How dare I question yoga, or maybe better said yoga teachers? I never questioned my coaches when I was a kid, or at the University, they must know... Fast forward, I now have injury in my hip, SI joint and knee. I am hypermobile. I was so happy to be able to do some crazy shit aside from other numerous mental and spiritual benefits . I was feeling the best in my entire life... until I wasn't.
My friend said "You are practicing yoga, you are not in a circus."
In "Hatha yoga pradipika" it is said that yoga is poison for those who are not handling it properly. In the west, people approach yoga in a, lets say, questionable manner. We must question this questionable manner.
Once again, Adriene is the truest yogi I have met in a sense that her philosophy alignes with love and nurturing as opposed to perfection and violence towards yourself.
If you do your reserch on the internet you will be shocked with the amount of injury that comes from not using yoga as it was meant. I must now learn from the pain and that is where true yoga begins. Peace ğŸ™
